Posts.Content: That's very interesting - I hadn't seen the BBC article about Herceptin.  I've just had my third subcutaneous injection and am definitely still getting the original unless the generics are also trastuzumab?
Posts.Title: HNS England - Prescribing Restrictions on Some Over The Counter D...

Posts.Content: Hi everyone. I'm commuting into London for work in the morning.  Then have a 2 mile walk home to collect the car and a 15 mile journey to the hospital for RT.  So far so good.  Will have 4/20 any minute now.  I'm amusing myself by taking random selfies (I'm trying to get a different colour gown every day) and have got the nurses to take a photo of me with the giant RT machine.  So far, so good.  Feeling very tired today but I think that's due to manic weekend of being at gigs, shopping, meals out and parkrun I hope you're all doing well too xx
Posts.Title: October 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: Hi fellow groupies I have my planning session on Thursday and then start RT on 24th.  Do you think the person who does the little tattoos will do requests only I don't want three little dots, I want OMG  I need to ring them tomorrow and they've managed to book one RT session 10 minutes before my Herceptin appointment is due to finish which is in a hospital 20 miles away!  Another appointment interferes with my social life, so will get that moved too. It beginning to feel a lot like...laters cancer  Good luck everyone xxx
Posts.Title: October 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a WLE and 3 sentinel nodes removed on Thursday and I really recommend the recobra (www.recoheart,com) which was recommended on a blog.  No wires, front fastening, so easy to put on without overstretching your armpits.  They also come in all sorts of sizes and super comfy.  In fact - so comfy, I walked 7 miles in mine today! Good luck!
Posts.Title: Best bra after sentinal lymph node biopsy

Posts.Content: Hey HappyFeet1 I took 2 weeks off but my day job involves me sitting on my backside.  I went back because I felt fine and that is the main point.  You MUST do what feels right for you, don't be pressured into going back before you're ready.  If your work are supportive, then even more reason to take your time. Congrats on the lymph node result (same here) such a relief! Luthien
Posts.Title: how long off work after lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy

Posts.Content: Hello, I too, was diagnosed from my very first screening just 2 weeks after my 50th birthday in Feb 2018.  I got the callback and had mammogram again, US and biopsy and was told it was definitely cancer there and then.  Mine was 6.5 CM but very flat, hence why I hadn't noticed it (felt like such an idiot).   You sound much more organised than I was, I went to all my appointments on my own and ended up waiting for my copy of the letter sent to the GP to remember what was said in most of them!  It's really worth getting someone calm and organised to go with you, who can write down any answers for you.  I had a good friend who wanted to go but she would have been a nightmare as she's quite bossy and emotional and I imagined her demanding second opinions and annoying everyone :)   Think about what you want to ask and write down questions - what is my treatment plan and in what order e.g. surgery, chemo, radiotherapy  (I had to have chemo before surgery due to type)?  When will it start?  What other tests do I need first?  If you need chemo or radio, ask if your hospital provide free parking.  My chemo hospital does but my radio one gives you a discount. Also, once you have a cancer diagnosis you're entitled to free prescriptions, you'll be assigned a Breast Cancer Nurse (who'll probably be at your next appointment if you've not already met her) so ask her for the form. Top tips - take everything one step at a time.  Just think about the next appointment or next bit of treatment and get all the information you need for that.  You'll be bombarded with information that'll make it seem quite scary.  I found the massive lists of chemo side affects really daunting but you'd be jolly unlucky to get all or even most of them -  be honest with your health care team - don't "battle through" - if you're in pain, feel sick, etc tell them and they'll prescribe you meds to help.  Take all the help you need from your healthcare team and from your friends and family and everyone here. I'd also really recommend this book (it's just been released and I wish it'd been around when I was diagnosed.  The Complete Guide to Breast Cancer: How To Feel Empowered and Take Control.  It's written by two doctors who've also both had breast cancer. Best wishes!
Posts.Title: Just joined the start line!

Posts.Content: Hi Val36 Great news from the surgery!  I'm HER2+ so had to have chemo before surgery (currently doing radiotherapy) so not in the same boat.  You're right that it is your decision - if it were me, I'd skip the chemo for that low risk, chemo itself carries risk to your health.  You've been given clear margins too, which is brill. I'm sure someone who has been in your shoes will come along soon with their thoughts. Best wishes for the remainder of your treatment (whichever path you choose)
Posts.Title: What to do for the best

Posts.Content: Hi everyone. I turned 50 at the end of last month and got my first routine mammogram through.  I was recalled and had that second appointment today - just assumed it was a dodgy picture as I don't have any symptoms.  Anyway, had another (very squashy) mammogram on right boob and then called in to see doctor, who very matter-of-factly told my that it was cancer!  Did ultrasound and took biopsies from boob and axy-something (armpit).  Bandaged me up and sent me off with a letter to come back to see consultant on 27th. I'm a bit stunned - I've literally just resigned from my job of 31 years and signed a contract for a new job this Monday which I start next Monday.  My husband is currently out of contact in Asia until I collect him from the airport on Saturday (and knows nothing about this).  I'm currently consoling myself with a Pimms! I think I'm more annoyed at the timing than the diagnosis.  Sorry for the rant. Can someone tell me what to expect at the consultant appointment - good questions to ask etc. Thanks in advance x
Posts.Title: Just back from follow-up appointment after mammogram - bad news!

Posts.Content: Morning everyone.  Surprisingly good sleep (despite horrid cold) and no pain from biopsies which is great.  I'd just finished having my hallway, stairs and landing decorated yesterday and today was massive clean up as everywhere is covered in dust from plastering.  The doc said I wasn't allowed to do this for 24 hours.  30 minutes ago, two of my friends turned up armed with cleaning gear and are currently blitzing the kitchen. Already feel like a total fraud - but, silver linings eh
Posts.Title: Just back from follow-up appointment after mammogram - bad news!

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for the reply.  I have a week of induction next week, so think I'll do that and then say as I'll need to take the day off to see the consultant.  It's a civil service job so I'm hoping that they'll be a bit more reasonable.  Three months ago, I was still with Local Gov where I'd been fr 30 years and this wouldn't have been an extra worry.  Meh. Anyway - I'm having a Pimms now.  Any excuse eh!
Posts.Title: Just back from follow-up appointment after mammogram - bad news!

Posts.Content: Thanks.  She did mention that she could feel some lumps and some thickening but I was completely unaware (dozy mare that I am). Someone from the helpline is going to call me back about the work situation.  So, I'm hoping that will be OK.  I'm not worried about the cancer diagnosis as that'll be what it'll be but it took at year in recruitment and security clearance to get this job and I'm so looking forward to it and I'm worried that this will **** it up. Anyway - will find out soon enough,  friends are on their way over.  Vodka is the way forward Thanks for all the responses, it's already reassuring xx
Posts.Title: Just back from follow-up appointment after mammogram - bad news!
Just back from follow-up appointment after mammogram - bad news!

Posts.Content: To add to the fun, my PET scan got cancelled this morning and not scheduled now until next Thursday.  I'm zen with this now - what will be, will be.  It also meant that I didn't have to fast, so have scoffed a bar of coconut ice (silver linings eh)
Posts.Title: Possible bone mets - scanxiety central!!

Posts.Content: Hi, OK - so this post is just going to be a bit of a download (sorry).  I'm not sure what I'm hoping for in response except someone with a magic wand to make this nightmare go away! So - last month I went for my first routine screening as was just about to turn 50.  Got a recall and told I had breast cancer (shocked as no symptoms).  The biopsy showed invasive duct cancer, 50mm tumour P3 but the node was clear - hurrah!  Packed off for a CT scan and bone scan.  HER2+ mildly ER+, PR-.  I have my first round of FECT on the 16th and sailed through it - all good (was a bit nauseous on the night of chemo and was out and about from the day after)! Last week, I got the results and although the bone scan was clear, the surgeon said there were spots on my lung which they weren't worried about as looked like old infection and a spot on my hip which they didn't know what it was but would send me for a PET scan.  I looked a bit confused and she gave me a thumbs up and said it's good news.  I went off thinking hurrah! Today, I saw my oncologist and asked her why I was having a PET scan if there was nothing to worry about.  She showed me my CT scan and not only was there a spot on my hip, there were lots of small ones in my pelvis.  She said it was strange that they didn't show on the bone scan but she can't rule out that they are not cancer but equally, might just be the way I'm made.   Having not even known I had any sort of cancer 5 weeks ago and sort of having been told that it's just in the breast - I'm REALLY struggling to cope with this.  I know it's stupid as it might not be bone mets but I just feel like I've been kicked from pillar to post by this bloody disease in this short time.  ARGGGHHHHH!! Sorry - that really was a download,  it all seems out of control
Posts.Title: Possible bone mets - scanxiety central!!

Posts.Content: Thanks @toxophilite  (I don't know how to tag and now I've got weird highlighting going on) LOL! It just hit me a bit hard today and I've been sailing along merrily at work, doing Park Run, out with friends just like normal and I feel so well, it still surprises me that I have any sort of cancer.  It feels like every appointment provides worse news than the last. I'm sure everyone has these feelings and I'd like to extend a group hug to everyone out there dealing with this too xxx
Posts.Title: Possible bone mets - scanxiety central!!

Posts.Content: Hi Poppy58 I had a blood clot in my arm whilst I had a PICC line (although not in the vein that was in, just a random occurrence like yours)!  I ended up on the injections for about 4 months.  In fact, the only reason I stopped taking them was that I asked at my pre-assessment for surgery if I needed more as was about to run out, but nobody ever got back to me.  So I just stopped.  That was about 3 months ago now and everything is fine.  My Onc did say it could be up to 6 months though. Good luck!
Posts.Title: PICC Line and Blood clots

Posts.Content: Hi Lou1234 I can't add anything more apart from to say, do please ask away in this group - there is always someone along to provide advice, signpost you to the right support or just a listening ear and a virtual hug. I would definitely advise that you call the Macmillan helpline about finances / work.  They're really knowledgeable.   Best Wishes x
Posts.Title: Hello, I’m new to this and would love a friendly hello
